txt: Park Jihyo, South Korean singer

entities.title: Jihyo
entities.description: Park Ji-hyo, known mononymously as Jihyo (Korean: 지효), is a South Korean singer. She is the leader of the K-pop girl group Twice under JYP Entertainment.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kan B'alam I, ruler of Palenque (b. 524)

entities.title: Kan B'alam I
entities.description: Kan Bahlam I, also known as Chan Bahlum I, was an ajaw of the Maya city-state of Palenque. He acceded to the throne on April 6, 572 at age 47 and ruled until his death. Kan Bahlam was most likely the younger brother of his predecessor, Ahkal Mo' Nahb II and probably son of K'an Joy Chitam I. He was the first ruler of Palenque to use the title K'inich, albeit inconsistently. The title is usually tr

entities.title: Palenque
entities.description: Palenque, also anciently known as Lakamha, was a Maya city state in southern Mexico that perished in the 7th century. The Palenque ruins date from ca. 226 BC to ca. 799 AD. After its decline, it was overgrown by the jungle of cedar, mahogany, and sapodilla trees, but has since been excavated and restored. It is located near the Usumacinta River in the Mexican state of Chiapas, about 130 km (81 mi)

heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Stephen III (b. 720)

entities.title: Pope Stephen III
entities.description: Pope Stephen III was the bishop of Rome and ruler of the Papal States from 7 August 768 to his death. Stephen was a Benedictine monk who worked in the Lateran Palace during the reign of Pope Zachary. In the midst of a tumultuous contest by rival factions to name a successor to Pope Paul I, Stephen was elected with the support of the Roman officials. He summoned the Lateran Council of 769, which so

heading: Deaths
txt: Ramiro I, king of Asturias

entities.title: Ramiro I of Asturias
entities.description: Ramiro I was king of Asturias from 842 until his death in 850. Son of King Bermudo I, he became king following a succession struggle after his predecessor, Alfonso II, died without children. During his turbulent reign, he fended off attacks from both Vikings and Moors. Architecturally, his recreational palace Santa María del Naranco and other buildings used the ramirense style that prefigured Roma

entities.title: Kingdom of Asturias
entities.description: The Kingdom of Asturias was a kingdom in the Iberian Peninsula founded by the Visigothic nobleman Pelagius. It was the first Christian political entity established after the Umayyad conquest of Visigothic Hispania in 718 or 722. That year, Pelagius defeated an Umayyad army at the Battle of Covadonga, in what is usually regarded as the beginning of the Reconquista.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexios Megas Komnenos, first Emperor of Trebizond

entities.title: Alexios I of Trebizond
entities.description: Alexios I Megas Komnenos or Alexius I Megas Comnenus was, with his brother David, the founder of the Empire of Trebizond and its ruler from 1204 until his death in 1222. The two brothers were the only male descendants of the Byzantine Emperor Andronikos I, who had been dethroned and killed in 1185, and thus claimed to represent the legitimate government of the Empire following the conquest of Cons

entities.title: Empire of Trebizond
entities.description: The Empire of Trebizond, or Trapezuntine Empire, was a monarchy and one of three successor rump states of the Byzantine Empire that flourished during the 13th through 15th centuries, consisting of the far northeastern corner of Anatolia and the southern Crimea. The empire was formed in 1204 with the help of the Georgian queen Tamar after the Georgian expedition in Chaldia and Paphlagonia, commande

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry II, Duke of Brabant (b. 1207)

entities.title: Henry II, Duke of Brabant
entities.description: Henry II of Brabant was Duke of Brabant and Lothier after the death of his father Henry I in 1235. His mother was Matilda of Boulogne.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles IV of France (b. 1294)

entities.title: Charles IV of France
entities.description: Charles IV, called the Fair in France and the Bald in Navarre, was last king of the direct line of the House of Capet, King of France and King of Navarre from 1322 to 1328. Charles was the third son of Philip IV; like his father, he was known as "the fair" or "the handsome".

heading: Deaths
txt: Sigismund of Bavaria (b. 1439)

entities.title: Sigismund of Bavaria
entities.description: Sigismund of Bavaria was a member of the Wittelsbach dynasty. He ruled as Duke of Bavaria-Munich from 1460 to 1467, and then as Duke of Bavaria-Dachau until his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Girolamo Aleandro, Italian cardinal (b. 1480)

entities.title: Girolamo Aleandro
entities.description: Girolamo Aleandro was an Italian cardinal, and the first cardinal appointed in pectore.

heading: Deaths
txt: Menas of Ethiopia

entities.title: Menas of Ethiopia
entities.description: Menas or Minas, throne name Admas Sagad I, was Emperor of Ethiopia from 1559 until his death, and a member of the Solomonic dynasty. He was a brother of Gelawdewos.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lawrence Humphrey, English theologian and academic (b. 1527)

entities.title: Lawrence Humphrey
entities.description: Lawrence Humphrey DD was an English theologian, who was President of Magdalen College, Oxford, and Dean successively of Gloucester and Winchester.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Alexander VIII (b. 1610)

entities.title: Pope Alexander VIII
entities.description: Pope Alexander VIII, born Pietro Vito Ottoboni, was Pope from 6 October 1689 to his death in 1691. He is to date the last pope to take the pontifical name of "Alexander" upon his election to the papacy.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Talbot, 1st Duke of Shrewsbury, English politician, Lord High Treasurer (b. 1660)

entities.title: Charles Talbot, 1st Duke of Shrewsbury
entities.description: Charles Talbot, 1st Duke of Shrewsbury, KG, PC was an English politician who was part of the Immortal Seven group that invited William III, Prince of Orange, to depose James II of England as monarch during the Glorious Revolution. He was appointed to several minor roles before the revolution, but came to prominence as a member of William's government. Born to Roman Catholic parents, he remained in

entities.title: Lord High Treasurer
entities.description: The post of Lord High Treasurer or Lord Treasurer was an English government position and has been a British government position since the Acts of Union of 1707. A holder of the post would be the third-highest-ranked Great Officer of State, below the Lord High Steward and the Lord High Chancellor of Great Britain.

heading: Deaths
txt: Augustus II the Strong, Polish king (b. 1670)

entities.title: Augustus II the Strong
entities.description: Augustus II, most commonly known as Augustus the Strong, was Elector of Saxony from 1694 as well as King of Poland and Grand Duke of Lithuania in the years 1697–1706 and from 1709 until his death in 1733. He belonged to the Albertine line of the House of Wettin.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Floyer, English physician and author (b. 1649)

entities.title: John Floyer (physician)
entities.description: Sir John Floyer was an English physician and author.

heading: Deaths
txt: Giuseppe Ottavio Pitoni, Italian organist and composer (b. 1657)

entities.title: Giuseppe Ottavio Pitoni
entities.description: Giuseppe Ottavio Pitoni was an Italian organist and composer. He became one of the leading musicians in Rome during the late Baroque era, the first half of the 18th century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bakar of Georgia (b. 1699)

entities.title: Bakar of Georgia
entities.description: Bakar was a Georgian royal prince (batonishvili) of the Mukhrani branch of the Bagrationi dynasty and served as regent of the Kingdom of Kartli from September 1716 to August 1719.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pierre François Xavier de Charlevoix, French priest and historian (b. 1682)

entities.title: Pierre François Xavier de Charlevoix
entities.description: Pierre François Xavier de Charlevoix, S.J. was a French Jesuit priest, traveller, and historian, often considered the first historian of New France. He had little interest for "a life of suffering and deprivation for the conversion of Indian souls", but "an eager curiosity concerning life".

heading: Deaths
txt: Sir Robert Rich, 4th Baronet, English field marshal and politician (b. 1685)

entities.title: Sir Robert Rich, 4th Baronet
entities.description: Field Marshal Sir Robert Rich, 4th Baronet was a British cavalry officer. As a junior officer he fought at the Battle of Schellenberg and at the Battle of Blenheim during the War of the Spanish Succession. He was then asked the raise a regiment to combat the threat from the Jacobite rising of 1715. He also served with the Pragmatic Army under the Earl of Stair at the Battle of Dettingen during the

heading: Deaths
txt: William Barrington, 2nd Viscount Barrington, English politician, Chancellor of the Exchequer (b. 1717)

entities.title: William Barrington, 2nd Viscount Barrington
entities.description: William Wildman Shute Barrington, 2nd Viscount Barrington, PC was a British politician who sat in the House of Commons for 38 years from 1740 to 1778. He was best known for his two periods as Secretary at War during Britain's involvement in the Seven Years War and American War of Independence.

entities.title: Chancellor of the Exchequer
entities.description: The Chancellor of the Exchequer, often abbreviated to the Chancellor, is a high ranking Minister of the Crown within the Government of the United Kingdom, and head of Her Majesty's Treasury. As one of the four Great Offices of State, the chancellor is a senior member of the British Cabinet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Archibald Murphey, American judge and politician (b. 1777)

entities.title: Archibald Murphey
entities.description: Archibald DeBow Murphey was an attorney, jurist, and politician in North Carolina who was known as the "Father of Education" in his state. While serving as a state senator, he proposed establishing a funded program for public education in the lower grades, in addition to creating public works to enhance economic development in the state.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary Shelley, English novelist and playwright (b. 1797)

entities.title: Mary Shelley
entities.description: Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley was an English novelist who wrote the Gothic novel Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus (1818), which is considered an early example of science fiction. She also edited and promoted the works of her husband, the Romantic poet and philosopher Percy Bysshe Shelley. Her father was the political philosopher William Godwin and her mother was the philosopher and feminist a

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Serov, Russian composer and critic (b. 1820)

entities.title: Alexander Serov
entities.description: Alexander Nikolayevich Serov was a Russian composer and music critic. He is notable as one of the most important music critics in Russia during the 1850s and 1860s and as the most significant Russian composer in the period between Dargomyzhsky's Rusalka and the works of Rimsky-Korsakov, Mussorgsky, and Tchaikovsky.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Henry Sanderson, American lawyer and politician, 22nd Mayor of San Francisco (b. 1824)

entities.title: George Henry Sanderson
entities.description: George Henry Sanderson was a politician of the United States Republican Party. Sanderson was born in Boston, Massachusetts, and traveled to San Francisco during the 1849 Gold Rush in California. He served as the 22nd Mayor of San Francisco from January 5, 1891, to January 3, 1893.

entities.title: Mayor of San Francisco
entities.description: The mayor of the City and County of San Francisco is the head of the executive branch of the San Francisco city and county government. The officeholder has the duty to enforce city laws, and the power to either approve or veto bills passed by the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, the legislative branch. The mayor serves a four-year term and is limited to two successive terms. Because of San Fran

heading: Deaths
txt: Constantin von Ettingshausen, Austrian geologist and botanist (b. 1826)

entities.title: Constantin von Ettingshausen
entities.description: Constantin Freiherr von Ettingshausen was an Austrian botanist known for his paleobotanical studies of flora from the Tertiary era. He was the son of physicist Andreas von Ettingshausen.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sir George Stokes, Anglo-Irish physicist, mathematician, and politician (b. 1819)

entities.title: Sir George Stokes, 1st Baronet
entities.description: Sir George Gabriel Stokes, 1st Baronet, was an Anglo-Irish physicist and mathematician. Born in County Sligo, Ireland, Stokes spent all of his career at the University of Cambridge, where he was the Lucasian Professor of Mathematics from 1849 until his death in 1903. As a physicist, Stokes made seminal contributions to fluid mechanics, including the Navier–Stokes equations and to physical optics,

heading: Deaths
txt: Léon Serpollet, French businessman (b. 1858)

entities.title: Léon Serpollet
entities.description: Léon Serpollet was a French engineer and developer of flash steam boilers and steam automobiles.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carlos I of Portugal (b. 1863)

entities.title: Carlos I of Portugal
entities.description: Dom Carlos I, known as the Diplomat and the Martyr, was the King of Portugal from 1889 until his assassination in 1908. He was the first Portuguese king to die a violent death since Sebastian in 1578.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Boucaut, English-Australian politician, 11th Premier of South Australia (b. 1831)

entities.title: James Boucaut
entities.description: Sir James Penn Boucaut was a South Australian politician and Australian judge. He was a member of the South Australian House of Assembly on four occasions: from 1861 to 1862 for City of Adelaide, from 1865 to 1870 for West Adelaide (1865–1868) and The Burra (1868–1870), from 1871 to 1878 for West Torrens (1871–1875) and Encounter Bay (1875–1878), and a final stint in Encounter Bay in 1878.

entities.title: Premier of South Australia
entities.description: The Premier of South Australia is the head of government in the state of South Australia, Australia. The Government of South Australia follows the Westminster system, with a Parliament of South Australia acting as the legislature. The Premier is appointed by the Governor of South Australia, and by modern convention holds office by virtue of his or her ability to command the support of a majority o

heading: Deaths
txt: William Desmond Taylor, American actor and director (b. 1872)

entities.title: William Desmond Taylor
entities.description: William Desmond Taylor was an Anglo-Irish-American film director and actor. A popular figure in the growing Hollywood motion picture colony of the 1910s and early 1920s, Taylor directed fifty-nine silent films between 1914 and 1922 and acted in twenty-seven between 1913 and 1915.

heading: Deaths
txt: Maurice Prendergast, American painter (b. 1858)

entities.title: Maurice Prendergast
entities.description: Maurice Brazil Prendergast was an American Post-Impressionist artist who worked in oil, watercolor, and monotype. He exhibited as a member of The Eight, though the delicacy of his compositions and mosaic-like beauty of his style differed from the artistic intentions and philosophy of the group.

heading: Deaths
txt: Hughie Jennings, American baseball player and manager (b. 1869)

entities.title: Hughie Jennings
entities.description: Hugh Ambrose Jennings was an American professional baseball player, coach and manager from 1891 to 1925. Jennings was a leader, both as a batter and as a shortstop, with the Baltimore Orioles teams that won National League championships in 1894, 1895, and 1896. During those three seasons, Jennings had 355 runs batted in and hit .335, .386, and .401.

heading: Deaths
txt: Georgios Kondylis, Greek general and politician, 128th Prime Minister of Greece (b. 1878)

entities.title: Georgios Kondylis
entities.description: Georgios Kondylis was a general of the Greek army and Prime Minister of Greece. He was nicknamed Keravnos, Greek for "Thunder" or "Thunderbolt".

entities.title: Prime Minister of Greece
entities.description: The prime minister of the Hellenic Republic, colloquially referred to as the prime minister of Greece, is the head of government of the Hellenic Republic and the leader of the Greek Cabinet. The incumbent prime minister is Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who took office on 8 July 2019.

heading: Deaths
txt: Philip Francis Nowlan, American author, created Buck Rogers (b. 1888)

entities.title: Philip Francis Nowlan
entities.description: Philip Francis Nowlan was an American science fiction author, best known as the creator of Buck Rogers.

heading: Deaths
txt: Zacharias Papantoniou, Greek journalist and critic (b. 1877)

heading: Deaths
txt: Piet Mondrian, Dutch-American painter (b. 1872)

entities.title: Piet Mondrian
entities.description: Pieter Cornelis Mondriaan, after 1906 Piet Mondrian, was a Dutch painter and art theoretician who is regarded as one of the greatest artists of the 20th century. He is known for being one of the pioneers of 20th-century abstract art, as he changed his artistic direction from figurative painting to an increasingly abstract style, until he reached a point where his artistic vocabulary was reduced to

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicolae Dumitru Cocea, Romanian journalist, author, and activist (b. 1880)

entities.title: Nicolae Dumitru Cocea
entities.description: N. D. Cocea was a Romanian journalist, novelist, critic and left-wing political activist, known as a major but controversial figure in the field of political satire. The founder of many newspapers and magazines, including Viața Socială, Rampa, Facla and Chemarea, collaborating with writer friends such as Tudor Arghezi, Gala Galaction and Ion Vinea, he fostered and directed the development of early

heading: Deaths
txt: Herbert Stothart, American conductor and composer (b. 1885)

heading: Deaths
txt: Friedrich Paulus, German general (b. 1890)

entities.title: Friedrich Paulus
entities.description: Friedrich Wilhelm Ernst Paulus was a German field marshal during World War II who is best known for commanding the 6th Army during the Battle of Stalingrad. The battle ended in disaster for the Wehrmacht when Soviet forces encircled the Germans within the city, leading to the ultimate defeat and capture of about 265,000 German personnel, their Axis allies and collaborators.

heading: Deaths
txt: Clinton Davisson, American physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1888)

entities.title: Clinton Davisson
entities.description: Clinton Joseph Davisson was an American physicist who won the 1937 Nobel Prize in Physics for his discovery of electron diffraction in the famous Davisson–Germer experiment. Davisson shared the Nobel Prize with George Paget Thomson, who independently discovered electron diffraction at about the same time as Davisson.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

heading: Deaths
txt: Madame Sul-Te-Wan, American actress (b. 1873)

entities.title: Madame Sul-Te-Wan
entities.description: Madame Sul-Te-Wan was an American stage, film and television actress for over 50 years. The daughter of former slaves, she began her career in entertainment touring the East Coast with various theatrical companies and moved to California to become a member of the fledgling film community. She became known as a character actress, appeared in high-profile films such as The Birth of a Nation (1915) a

heading: Deaths
txt: Hedda Hopper, American actress and journalist (b. 1885)

entities.title: Hedda Hopper
entities.description: Hedda Hopper was an American gossip columnist and actress. At the height of her influence in the 1940s, her readership was 35 million. A strong supporter of the House Un-American Activities Committee (HUAC) hearings, Hopper named suspected communists and was a major proponent of the Hollywood blacklist. Hopper continued to write gossip until the end of her life, her work appearing in many magazine

entities.title: Death of Echol Cole and Robert Walker
entities.description: Echol Cole and Robert Walker were two sanitation workers killed in Memphis, Tennessee, United States, on February 1, 1968.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfréd Rényi, Hungarian mathematician and academic (b. 1921)

entities.title: Alfréd Rényi
entities.description: Alfréd Rényi was a Hungarian mathematician who made contributions in combinatorics, graph theory, number theory but mostly in probability theory.

heading: Deaths
txt: Werner Heisenberg, German physicist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1901)

entities.title: Werner Heisenberg
entities.description: Werner Karl Heisenberg was a German theoretical physicist and one of the key pioneers of quantum mechanics. He published his work in 1925 in a breakthrough paper. In the subsequent series of papers with Max Born and Pascual Jordan, during the same year, this matrix formulation of quantum mechanics was substantially elaborated. He is known for the uncertainty principle, which he published in 1927.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901; the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Pr

txt: George Whipple, American physician and pathologist, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1878)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Abdi İpekçi, Turkish journalist and activist (b. 1929)

entities.title: Abdi İpekçi
entities.description: Abdi İpekçi was a Turkish journalist, intellectual and an activist for human rights. He was murdered while editor-in-chief of one of the main Turkish daily newspapers Milliyet which then had a centre-left political stance.

heading: Deaths
txt: Donald Wills Douglas, Sr., American engineer and businessman, founded the Douglas Aircraft Company (b. 1892)

entities.title: Donald Wills Douglas, Sr.
entities.description: Donald Wills Douglas Sr. was an American aircraft industrialist and engineer.

entities.title: Douglas Aircraft Company
entities.description: The Douglas Aircraft Company was an American aerospace manufacturer based in Southern California. It was founded in 1921 by Donald Wills Douglas Sr. and later merged with McDonnell Aircraft in 1967 to form McDonnell Douglas, when it then operated as a division of McDonnell Douglas. McDonnell Douglas later merged with Boeing in 1997.

heading: Deaths

heading: Deaths
txt: Alva Myrdal, Swedish sociologist and politician, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1902)

entities.title: Alva Myrdal
entities.description: Alva Myrdal was a Swedish sociologist, diplomat and politician. She was a prominent leader of the disarmament movement. She, along with Alfonso García Robles, received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1982. She married Gunnar Myrdal in 1924.

entities.title: Nobel Peace Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Peace Prize is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Swedish industrialist, inventor, and armaments manufacturer Alfred Nobel, along with the prizes in Chemistry, Physics, Physiology or Medicine, and Literature. Since March 1901, it has been awarded annually to those who have "done the most or the best work for fraternity between nations, for the abolition or reduction

heading: Deaths
txt: Alessandro Blasetti, Italian director and screenwriter (b. 1900)

entities.title: Alessandro Blasetti
entities.description: Alessandro Blasetti was an Italian film director and screenwriter who influenced Italian neorealism with the film Quattro passi fra le nuvole. Blasetti was one of the leading figures in Italian cinema during the Fascist era. He is sometimes known as the "father of Italian cinema" because of his role in reviving the struggling industry in the late 1920s.

heading: Deaths
txt: Heather O'Rourke, American child actress (b. 1975)

entities.title: Heather O'Rourke
entities.description: Heather Michele O'Rourke was an American child actress. She made her debut after being discovered by director Steven Spielberg while visiting MGM studios. Spielberg promptly cast her in the horror film Poltergeist (1982) as Carol Anne Freeling, and O'Rourke earned recognition for her performance. She then reprised the role in the second and third installments. O'Rourke was also recognized for her

heading: Deaths
txt: Elaine de Kooning, American painter and academic (b. 1918)

entities.title: Elaine de Kooning
entities.description: Elaine Marie Catherine de Kooning was an Abstract Expressionist and Figurative Expressionist painter in the post-World War II era. She wrote extensively on the art of the period and was an editorial associate for Art News magazine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean Hamburger, French physician and surgeon (b. 1909)

entities.title: Jean Hamburger
entities.description: Jean Hamburger was a French physician, surgeon and essayist. He is particularly known for his contribution to nephrology, and for having performed the first renal transplantation in France in 1952.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ray Crawford, American race car driver, pilot, and businessman (b. 1915)

entities.title: Ray Crawford
entities.description: Ray Crawford was an American fighter ace, test pilot, race-car driver and businessman.

heading: Deaths
txt: Herb Caen, American journalist and author (b. 1916)

entities.title: Herb Caen
entities.description: Herbert Eugene Caen was a San Francisco humorist and journalist whose daily column of local goings-on and insider gossip, social and political happenings, and offbeat puns and anecdotes—"A continuous love letter to San Francisco"—appeared in the San Francisco Chronicle for almost sixty years and made him a household name throughout the San Francisco Bay Area.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Mellon, American art collector and philanthropist (b. 1907)

entities.title: Paul Mellon
entities.description: Paul Mellon was an American philanthropist and an owner/breeder of thoroughbred racehorses. He is one of only five people ever designated an "Exemplar of Racing" by the National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame. He was co-heir to one of America's greatest business fortunes, derived from the Mellon Bank created by his grandfather Thomas Mellon, his father Andrew W. Mellon, and his father's brother

heading: Deaths
txt: André D'Allemagne, Canadian political scientist and academic (b. 1929)

entities.title: André D'Allemagne
entities.description: André d'Allemagne was a translator, political science teacher, essayist and a militant for the independence of Quebec from Canada. Along with some 20 other people including Marcel Chaput and Jacques Bellemare, he was a founding member of the Rassemblement pour l'indépendance nationale (RIN).

heading: Deaths
txt: Aykut Barka, Turkish geologist and academic (b. 1951)

entities.title: Aykut Barka
entities.description: Aykut Barka was a Turkish earth scientist specialized in earthquake research. He is best known for his contributions to understanding the behaviour of the North Anatolian Fault Zone (NAFZ), one of the most dangerous active faults in the world.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Vernon, Canadian-American actor (b. 1932)

entities.title: John Vernon
entities.description: John Keith Vernon was a Canadian actor. He made a career in Hollywood after achieving initial television stardom in Canada. He was best known for playing Dean Wormer in Animal House, the Mayor in Dirty Harry and Fletcher in The Outlaw Josey Wales.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gian Carlo Menotti, Italian-American playwright and composer (b. 1911)

entities.title: Gian Carlo Menotti
entities.description: Gian Carlo Menotti was an Italian-American composer, librettist, director, and playwright who is primarily known for his output of 25 operas. Although he often referred to himself as an American composer, he kept his Italian citizenship. One of the most frequently performed opera composers of the 20th century, his most successful works were written in the 1940s and 1950s. Highly influenced by Giac

heading: Deaths
txt: Beto Carrero, Brazilian actor and businessman (b. 1937)

entities.title: Beto Carrero
entities.description: Beto Carrero was a Brazilian theme park owner and entertainer. He was the creator of the Beto Carrero World Park, in the municipality of Penha, on the northern coast of the Brazilian state of Santa Catarina, which is the largest theme park in Latin America and the third largest in the world.

heading: Deaths
txt: Don Cornelius, American television host and producer (b. 1936)

entities.title: Don Cornelius
entities.description: Donald Cortez Cornelius was an American television show host and producer who was best known as the creator of the nationally syndicated dance and music show Soul Train, which he hosted from 1971 until 1993. Cornelius sold the show to MadVision Entertainment in 2008.

entities.title: Mayor of New York City
entities.description: The mayor of New York City, officially Mayor of the City of New York, is head of the executive branch of the Government of New York City. The mayor's office administers all city services, public property, police and fire protection, most public agencies, and enforces all city and state laws within New York City.

entities.title: President of Guatemala
entities.description: The President of Guatemala, officially known as the President of the Republic of Guatemala, is the head of state and head of government of Guatemala, elected to a single four-year term. The position of President was created in 1839.
